title: Cross-linked RNA Immunoprecipitation
procedures: Preparation of beads and cells   Blocking of the beads: Wash 40 μl Anti-Flag M2 Affinity Gel twice with 900 μl of pure H2O (cold); add 400 μl IP lysis buffer +1% BSA; incubate at 4 °C (on a rotating wheel) overnight. Alternatively use 30 μl SepharoseG-Beads + specific antibody. The amount of antibody and beads to be used in the precoupling will need to be determined in preliminary experiments. Typically using 10 μg of Ig for coupling is a reasonable starting point.   Use 2 x 10 cm2 tissue culture plate per condition (this might vary depending on the cell type and the level of expression of the protein of interest). Do not process more than 10 plates at a time.   Transfect cells and incubate them for 48 h to express the tagged protein      Harvesting the cells   Remove medium, wash the cells once with phosphate buffered saline and add 1 ml 0.25% Trypsin (pre-heated to 37 °C). Incubate at 37 °C until the cells start to detach.    Add 5 ml DMEM including 10% fetal calf serum (pre-warmed to 37 °C) to inhibit the trypsin.   Remove the cells from the plate by pipetting.   Transfer the cells to a 15 ml conical tube and incubate on ice for 5 min.   Harvest cells 2 min at 100 x g at room temperature, decant the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 5 ml ice-cold phosphate buffered saline. Keep a 250 μl aliquot for Western blot analysis to be used as a transfection control.   Add 143 μl 37% formaldehyde (over a period of approximately 10 sec, treat all of the samples in the same way).   Place the 15 ml conical tubes on a rocking plate and shake for 10 min at room temperature.

Add 685 μl 2 M glycine (over a period of approximately 10 sec, treat all of the samples in the same way) to block the formaldehyde.   Place the 15 ml conical tubes on a rocking plate and shake for 5 min at room temperature.   Harvest cells by centrifugation for 2 min at 100 x g at room temperature.   Decant the supernatant and transfer the cell pellet to ice.   Wash the cells twice with 5 ml ice-cold phosphate buffered saline and harvest the cells 2 min at 100 x g at 4 °C.   Remove the supernatant from the cells after the last wash and add 1 ml of IP lysis buffer + 20 μl 0.1 M phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride + 20 μl complete protease inhibitor (50x) + 5 μl RNase inhibitor (40 U/μl) to each sample.   Sonicate the cells, keeping them on ice at all times, 10x (10 sec on, 10 sec off, Amplitude 15 μm) until the lysate is clear. Clean probe sonicator with RNaseZap between the samples to avoid contamination with RNases.   Transfer the cells to a 1.5 ml snap-cap tube and keep on ice.   Centrifuge the lysates for 3 min at 14,000 x g at room temperature and keep 50 μl of the supernatant as an INPUT control (used to standardize the qPCR analysis).      Immunoprecipitation   Add the rest of the lysate to the blocked beads and incubate overnight at 4 °C on a rotating wheel.   Wash the beads 5 times with 900 μl of IP lysis buffer collecting the beads by centrifugation for 1 min at 400 x g at room temperature.   Remove all of the supernatant after the last wash and add 100 μl of RIP buffer + 1 μl RNase inhibitor. Add 50 μl of RIP buffer to the INPUT control (step 18).

Incubate the samples and INPUT controls for 1 h at 70 °C to reverse the cross-link.   Centrifuge for 1 min at 400 x g at room temperature to sediment the beads and collect 100 μl of supernatant.   Extract the RNA with Trizol reagent (proceed according to the manufacturer’s instruction (Invitrogen)). Optional: Add 1 μl of Glycogen blue before precipitation of the RNA with Isopropanol to make the pellet visible. Precipitation can also be performed at -20 °C for 1 h to increase the amount of precipitated RNA.   DNAse treatment of the RNA to avoid contamination with genomic DNA.  Dilute the RNA pellet directly in DNase mastermix (per sample: 16 μl DEPC treated H2O, 2 μl DNaase buffer, 2 μl DNAse) in order to use all RNA in the following RT reaction and proceed after the manufacturer’s instruction (Roche).      Reverse transcription of the RNA into cDNA   BioScriptTM (Bioline) kit works well but other reverse transcriptase kits may also be used.  9 μl of the DNAse treated RNA was used in a reverse transcriptase-containing and a reverse transcriptase-minus (negative control) reaction for each sample. cDNA was primed with random hexamer primers and the reaction performed according to the manufacturer’s instructions.   Dilute the cDNA 1:4 and continue with quantitative real-time PCR analysis of target gene to identify specific changes in target mRNA level. Alternatively the cDNA can be used to generate a library.
